STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER
LANS ING
ELIZABETH HERTEL
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
October 3, 2025
Lindsey Lassanske
NEWAYGO/LAKE COUNTY DHHS
1018 E NEWELL ST,
WHITE CLOUD, MI, 49349-8795
Re: License #: CP620201323
Dear Lindsey Lassanske:
Attached is the Interim Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed on
October 2, 2025. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective
action plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this
letter and must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager, Jessica VandenHeuvel, at (616) 204-
6992.
P.O. BOX 30650 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov • (517) 335-1980

Sincerely,
Melinda Gubbins, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
701 S. Elmwood, Ste. 11
Traverse City, MI 49684
enclosure
2

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the following:
CPA Rule 400.12404 Placement
• (6) An agency must document, in the child's record, within 7 calendar days
after placement, the information specified in R 400.12417(1) and all the
following information:
• (a) All the following child characteristics:
• (iii) Height and weight.
Two of eight foster care files reviewed did not have physical characteristics
completed.
CPA Rule 400.12415 Unusual incident reporting policy
• (1) An agency must adhere to the following incident reporting protocols:
• (a) Immediately notify the child's parents; the department licensing
authority; the lawyer guardian ad litem and court, as applicable; the
department; and the foster child's parents, if any of the following
occurs:
• (iv) Any medical and mental illness or condition that results in
treatment at a hospital emergency room or inpatient
hospitalization of a foster child.
2

Two of eight foster care files reviewed did not have documentation an incident
report was completed and required parties notified when youth required treatment at
a hospital emergency room.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
9/3/2024 RENEWAL, CAP approved 10/10/2024
CPA Rule 400.12417 Foster parent information
• (1) An agency shall provide a foster parent with all the following information
before the placement or replacement of a child:
• (a) Child's name.
• (b) Child’s date of birth.
• (c) Available known information about the child’s health.
• (d) Any known history of abuse or neglect of the child.
• (e) All known emotional and psychological factors relating to the care
of the child.
• (f) All known behaviors of the child.
• (g) Circumstances necessitating placement or replacement of the
child.
• (h) Any other known information to enable the foster parent to provide
a stable, safe, and healthy environment for the foster child and the
foster family, including information about siblings who do not reside in
the foster home as provided in federal law.
One of eight foster care files reviewed did not have documentation the caregiver
was provided the information in subsections (a-h) of this rule prior to placement.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
9/3/2024 RENEWAL, CAP approved 10/10/2024
9/8/2023 INTERIM, CAP approved 9/18/2023
CPA Rule 400.12418 Development of service plans
• (2) An agency shall complete written service plans for each child and parent
or parents, as follows:
• (b) Within 120 calendar days after the initial removal and at least once
every 90 calendar days thereafter.
Two of eight foster care files reviewed did not have a service plan completed timely
as required.
3

REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
9/3/2024 RENEWAL, CAP approved 10/10/2024
9/8/2023 INTERIM, CAP approved 9/18/2023
CPA Rule 400.12510 Independent living agreement
• (2) The agreement must be signed and dated by the youth and the social
service worker. The agreement must be reviewed with the youth at least once
every 90 calendar days and a copy provided to the youth.
One of three independent living files reviewed did not have documentation the
independent living contract was updated and provided to youth quarterly as
required.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
9/3/2024 RENEWAL, CAP approved 10/10/2024
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
• Date of completion should be listed for CPR/First Aid certification.
• All required signatures must also include a date.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
• There was no consultation requested or required.
VI. EVALUATION OF PERIOD UNDER REVIEW
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
There were no incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted 1 acceptable corrective action plans (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows: The
agency renewal inspection was completed on 9/3/24 and the CAP was approved
on 10/10/24. The agency was cited for 12 violations, 4 of which were repeated this
year. Of those 4 there was an improvement in individual incident of non-
compliance within 3 of the violation areas and a slight increase in number of
individual incidents in the other 1 area. In 2023, 7 violations were established, 2 of
which were repeated this year. All of the repeated violations remain close to the
4

same number of individual incidents of non-compliances. The agency will need to
establish additional corrective planning for the repeated violations to ensure a
reduction of incidents.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The Chief Administrator assessment was reviewed. The chief administrator
indicated the agency experienced several leaves of absence, allocation changes
and a county reconfiguration. However, the previous year CAP has had a positive
impact on overall agency compliance. The assessment noted the development of
the CAP was done in partnership with direct staff as well as supervisors.
Financial Overview
NA
Staff and Youth Interviews
Interviews were conducted with two staff via telephone. Staff reported feeling
supported by the agency and the transition from a dual office to a tri county office
has gone well. Staff did not report any concerns.
Description of Agency Walk Through
The agency maintains sufficient office space, equipment and supplies to ensure
delivery of foster care and licensing services. All files were stored securely and
there is a cross shredder for CHRI.
VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
There were 3 safety alerts identified.
Safety Alert #1: The home of relative caregiver was found to be missing a carbon
monoxide detector.
Resolution: The agency provided the caregiver with a carbon monoxide detector. A
picture was provided as verification showing the detector installed.
Safety Alert #2: The home of relative caregiver was found to be missing a carbon
monoxide detector.
Resolution: The agency provided the caregiver with a carbon monoxide detector. A
picture was provided as verification showing the detector installed.
Safety Alert #3: The home of relative caregiver was found to be missing a working
smoke detector near the upstairs bedrooms and also in the basement.
Resolution: The agency provided the caregiver with two smoke detectors. Pictures
were provided as verification showing one was installed at the start of the hallway
leading to the bedrooms and the other was installed at the base of the basement
stairs. Both were tested and verified to be in working order.
5

VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the agency continue on their regular license.
__________10/2/2025________________________
Melinda Gubbins Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
October 3, 2025
